R15.nl_constraint: City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there

children.nl_constraint: Aircraft located in city2 cannot have their fuel replenished to full capacity

content.text:
<documents>
<pddl_domain>
;; Enrico Scala (enricos83@gmail.com) and Miquel Ramirez (miquel.ramirez@gmail.com)
(define (domain zenotravel)
        ;(:requirements :typing :fluents)
        (:types
                locatable city - object
                aircraft person - locatable
        )
        (:predicates
                (located ?x - locatable ?c - city)
                (in ?p - person ?a - aircraft)
        )
        (:functions
                (fuel ?a - aircraft)
                (distance ?c1 - city ?c2 - city)
                (slow-burn ?a - aircraft)
                (fast-burn ?a - aircraft)
                (capacity ?a - aircraft)
                (total-fuel-used)
                (onboard ?a - aircraft)
                (zoom-limit ?a - aircraft)

                (n_board ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_debark ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_flyslow ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_flyfast ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_refuel ?a - aircraft)
        )

        (:action board
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?p ?c)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (located ?p ?c))
                        (in ?p ?a)
                        (increase (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_board ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action debark
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (in ?p ?a)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (in ?p ?a))
                        (located ?p ?c)
                        (decrease (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_debark ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action flyslow
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a))))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total-fuel-used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyslow ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action flyfast
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (<= (onboard ?a) (zoom-limit ?a)))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total-fuel-used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyfast ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action refuel
                :parameters (?a - aircraft)
                :precondition (and (> (capacity ?a) (fuel ?a))

                )
                :effect (and (assign (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))
                        (increase (n_refuel ?a) 1))
        )

)
</pddl_domain>
<pddl_problem>
(define (problem ZTRAVEL-3-10)
(:domain zenotravel)
(:objects
	plane1 - aircraft
	plane2 - aircraft
	plane3 - aircraft
	person1 - person
	person2 - person
	person3 - person
	person4 - person
	person5 - person
	person6 - person
	person7 - person
	person8 - person
	person9 - person
	person10 - person
	city0 - city
	city1 - city
	city2 - city
	city3 - city
	city4 - city
	city5 - city
	)
(:init
	(located plane1 city4)
	(= (capacity plane1) 2326)
	(= (fuel plane1) 205)
	(= (slow-burn plane1) 1)
	(= (fast-burn plane1) 2)
	(= (onboard plane1) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane1) 10)
	(located plane2 city2)
	(= (capacity plane2) 12132)
	(= (fuel plane2) 1469)
	(= (slow-burn plane2) 4)
	(= (fast-burn plane2) 9)
	(= (onboard plane2) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane2) 9)
	(located plane3 city3)
	(= (capacity plane3) 5204)
	(= (fuel plane3) 1532)
	(= (slow-burn plane3) 2)
	(= (fast-burn plane3) 7)
	(= (onboard plane3) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane3) 8)
	(located person1 city1)
	(located person2 city2)
	(located person3 city1)
	(located person4 city4)
	(located person5 city5)
	(located person6 city1)
	(located person7 city0)
	(located person8 city2)
	(located person9 city1)
	(located person10 city5)
	(= (distance city0 city0) 0)
	(= (distance city0 city1) 619)
	(= (distance city0 city2) 565)
	(= (distance city0 city3) 886)
	(= (distance city0 city4) 596)
	(= (distance city0 city5) 766)
	(= (distance city1 city0) 619)
	(= (distance city1 city1) 0)
	(= (distance city1 city2) 561)
	(= (distance city1 city3) 756)
	(= (distance city1 city4) 760)
	(= (distance city1 city5) 980)
	(= (distance city2 city0) 565)
	(= (distance city2 city1) 561)
	(= (distance city2 city2) 0)
	(= (distance city2 city3) 657)
	(= (distance city2 city4) 702)
	(= (distance city2 city5) 639)
	(= (distance city3 city0) 886)
	(= (distance city3 city1) 756)
	(= (distance city3 city2) 657)
	(= (distance city3 city3) 0)
	(= (distance city3 city4) 546)
	(= (distance city3 city5) 510)
	(= (distance city4 city0) 596)
	(= (distance city4 city1) 760)
	(= (distance city4 city2) 702)
	(= (distance city4 city3) 546)
	(= (distance city4 city4) 0)
	(= (distance city4 city5) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city0) 766)
	(= (distance city5 city1) 980)
	(= (distance city5 city2) 639)
	(= (distance city5 city3) 510)
	(= (distance city5 city4) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city5) 0)
	(= (total-fuel-used) 0)
)
(:goal (and
	(located plane1 city4)
	(located person1 city4)
	(located person2 city5)
	(located person3 city4)
	(located person4 city0)
	(located person5 city2)
	(located person6 city3)
	(located person8 city0)
	(located person9 city3)
	(located person10 city4)
	))

(:metric minimize (total-fuel-used))





)
</pddl_problem>

<information>
The user will give as input a natural language constraint that must be translated into PDDL3.0. The translation will be used by a PDDL planner.
</information>

<instructions> 
- Translate the input constraint into correct PDDL3.0.
- The resulting PDDL3.0 constraint must capture the same meaning as the initial input constraint.
- Remember that PDDL3.0 constraints are state-based. They can only refer to existing precates and fluents, thus, not to actions.
- Be sure to include temporal logic like operators in your translation.
- Format your answer such as there is no preambule and such that the PDDL translation is between the tags <pddl> and </pddl>.
</instructions>

<user_input>
Aircraft located in city2 cannot have their fuel replenished to full capacity
</user_input>

Let me analyze this constraint and the PDDL domain to understand how to translate it.

The constraint is: "Aircraft located in city2 cannot have their fuel replenished to full capacity"

Looking at the domain, I can see:
1. There's a `refuel` action that sets fuel to capacity: `(assign (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))`
2. There's a predicate `(located ?x - locatable ?c - city)` to check location
3. There's a function `(fuel ?a - aircraft)` for current fuel
4. There's a function `(capacity ?a - aircraft)` for maximum capacity

The constraint says that if an aircraft is located in city2, then it cannot have its fuel equal to its capacity.

In PDDL3.0, this would be a state constraint. The constraint needs to express that for any aircraft, if it's located in city2, then its fuel cannot be equal to its capacity.

This can be written as:
- For all aircraft ?a, if (located ?a city2) then NOT (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))

In PDDL3.0 syntax, this would be:
```
(forall (?a - aircraft) 
  (imply (located ?a city2) 
         (not (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a)))))
```

Wait, let me double-check the PDDL3.0 syntax for constraints. In PDDL3.0, state constraints are typically written using `always` or other temporal operators.

Actually, looking more carefully, the constraint is about preventing the state where an aircraft in city2 has full fuel. This is a state constraint that should always hold.

The PDDL3.0 way to express this would be:
```
(always (forall (?a - aircraft) 
           (imply (located ?a city2) 
                  (not (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))))))


```

I'll formalize the constraint to ensure aircraft in city2 maintain a fuel level below full capacity. The key is using the `always` temporal operator to create a persistent rule preventing complete refueling in this specific location.

The user will give as input a constraint in natural language. This constraint must be used as a transjectory hard constraint for the solution plan of the given the PDDL problem. 
</information>

<instructions> 
- Refine the user constraint to make it applicable to the given PDDL problem.
- You can rephrase and decompose the initial constraint into several other contraints.
- These constraints should be complementary and they will be later combined with AND operators.
- Constraints must be state-based and follow a Linear Temporal Logic. So constraints can't directly refer to actions.
- Avoid explicit PDDL language in your answer, the user can't understand PDDL.
- The set of all refined constraints must capture the meaning of the initial user constraint. 
- Format your answer as a clear and concise numbered list between the tags <constraints> and </constraints>. There should be no subitems, only the list of refined constraints.
- After, add 1 or 2 sentences to explain your choice of decomposition between the tags <explanation> and </explanation>.

    <constraints>

        2. [natural_language_constraint_2]
        ...
    </constraints>
    <explanation>
        [consice_explanation]
    </explanation>
</instructions>

<user_input>
City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there
</user_input>

Let me analyze the user constraint: "City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there"

Looking at the PDDL domain, I can see there's a "refuel" action that allows aircraft to refuel. The constraint is saying that this refuel action should not be allowed when the aircraft is in city2.

In PDDL terms, this would mean that whenever an aircraft is located in city2, it cannot perform the refuel action. But I need to express this in natural language without using PDDL terminology.

The constraint is essentially saying that:
- No aircraft should refuel while located in city2

Since constraints must be state-based and follow Linear Temporal Logic, I need to think about this in terms of states rather than actions. 

The refuel action in PDDL has the effect of setting the fuel of an aircraft to its capacity. So if I want to prevent refueling in city2, I need to ensure that:
- If an aircraft is in city2, its fuel level should not suddenly jump to its maximum capacity (which would indicate refueling occurred)

But this is tricky to express as a state constraint. Let me think of another approach.

Actually, looking at the PDDL domain more carefully, the refuel action increases a counter "n_refuel" each time it's used. So I could constrain that:
- The refuel counter for any aircraft should not increase while that aircraft is located in city2

But again, this is referencing the action indirectly.

Let me think about this differently. The user wants to prevent refueling in city2. In terms of states, this means:
- No plane should ever have its fuel restored to full capacity while located in city2

Or more precisely:
- If a plane is located in city2, it should not have its fuel level increase to its maximum capacity

But this is still quite complex to express as a state constraint.

Actually, let me reconsider. The user constraint is about preventing the refuel action from happening in city2. 

I'll focus on a clear, straightforward interpretation of the constraint. Aircraft in city2 cannot increase their fuel levels. This means when a plane is in city2, its fuel should remain constant - no additional fuel can be added. The key is preventing any fuel gain while the aircraft is located in this specific city.

The constraint fundamentally restricts fuel replenishment in city2, ensuring that planes cannot restore or increase their fuel levels while present in this location. I want to prevent refueling in city2 by ensuring aircraft cannot restore their fuel to full capacity while located there. The core constraint is blocking the transition from partial to maximum fuel levels during an aircraft's stay in this location. Essentially, city2 lacks the infrastructure to support complete fuel replenishment, maintaining aircraft at their current or reduced fuel states. I'm exploring state-based constraints to prevent refueling in city2. The core requirement is maintaining the current fuel state of aircraft while they're located in this specific city. Essentially, any aircraft in city2 should not experience fuel level increases or complete refueling. The constraint focuses on preserving the existing fuel quantity, ensuring no restoration to maximum capacity occurs during the aircraft's stay in city2.

The key principle is preventing fuel-related state changes that would artificially improve an aircraft's fuel status. This means keeping the fuel level static and blocking any mechanisms that might artificially replenish or maximize fuel reserves while the aircraft remains in this location. I'll track the refueling counter to prevent aircraft from replenishing fuel while in city2. The key is ensuring no fuel restoration occurs for planes at this location, maintaining the constraint that city2 lacks fuel resources. This single rule effectively blocks refueling operations, directly addressing the user's specification about fuel unavailability in the specific city.

<constraints>
1. Aircraft located in city2 cannot have their fuel replenished to full capacity
</constraints>

<explanation>
The constraint prevents any refueling operations in city2 by ensuring that aircraft stationed there cannot restore their fuel to maximum levels, which is the defining characteristic of the refuel action in the domain.
</explanation>
